text: (Translated by Google) Very disappointing clinic! My guinea pig (4 years old) got sick on Friday evening. Since there was no normal vet available at 11:00 p.m. Friday evening, I had to go to the Bessys Clinic for better or worse (NOT recommended at all). An x-ray was taken and it was found that she had a bloated stomach. She was also drooling profusely, had watery eyes, and had odd breathing. At the Bessys Clinic, after asking several times, I was told that everything else was fine with her. I received medication and treated it at home. The next morning the condition had not improved at all and I had the feeling that something was wrong. She still had the same symptoms and wasn't eating anymore. Since I didn't want to go to the Bessys Clinic anymore, I tried the VetTrust small animal practice in Regensdorf. They told me they didn't have time, only an emergency appointment at 11:30. After I said it was urgent because she wasn't eating anymore, I was able to drop her off and pick her up again after 2 hours. When I picked it up I asked what she has now. I was told she has a bloated stomach (according to the X-ray of the Bessys). I asked why she was salivating and breathing weirdly. I was told it was because of the medication (she was salivating BEFORE the medication). I asked again if she really just had a bloated stomach. I was told YES. I should feed her and continue to give the medication. I asked if she had eaten during those two hours at the clinic. I was told NO. I'm wondering, was my guinea pig even properly examined in those two hours?! Or did you just take a quick look at the x-rays?! If she doesn't eat, why not feed her?! It is deadly if guinea pigs do not eat for a long time! What did I leave her there for 2 hours? For NOTHING!!! I am very disappointed with the way this clinic is doing! 24 hours later, despite medication every 4 hours, the condition has not improved at all. We then drove straight to the animal hospital in Zurich. There they found out that the bloating came from pneumonia. Despite ventilation and infusions, she unfortunately did not survive the night and died on Monday morning :-(! It's not for nothing that I take my guinea pig to a second clinic, that should have set alarm bells ringing too! I find it incredible that they just left this poor mouse in her basket for 2 hours and did nothing for her except give me the same diagnosis that I already knew! NO MORE VetTrust! Very incompetent! It seems to me that they have the attitude "It's ONLY a guinea pig". I feel very pissed off! I am very sad that our mouse had to go through this and only half the diagnosis was made and not even examined in detail! RIP little mouse! :-( (Original) Sehr enttÃ¤uschende Klinik! response_from_owner: (Translated by Google) Dear Mr. Customer We are sorry that you perceived our service in this way. Our therapeutic approaches are always based on a medical background. Drugs that have a supportive effect have their justification. They help to accelerate the healing process and increase the well-being of the animals. A good example of this is a skin allergy sufferer who is only given anti-itch medication without any supportive improvement in the function of the skin barrier. This animal will have problems far more often than one receiving supportive medication. In order to prescribe prescription drugs, we must first examine the animals clinically to assess whether medication is appropriate. Especially when antibiotics are administered, we always have to see the animal beforehand, since something in the clinical picture may have changed and the antibiotics are no longer indicated. Prescribing antibiotics is strictly regulated by law. As veterinarians, we have to report every antibiotic that we prescribe to Swissmedic. It is essential that antibiotics are indicated because repeated administration without a clear indication can breed resistance, which unfortunately is becoming more and more the case and can also become a major problem in the future if we are not careful with it. That's why it's not about profit for us, but rather about the health of all animals, as we want to continue working with antibiotics in the future. Immediate payment applies to all VetTrust locations throughout Switzerland. For larger amounts, a part must be paid in advance, and customers can then pay the rest by invoice. Since we are aware that many customers get into difficulties if the costs are higher, we have developed a special insurance together with the insurance company SmartPaws, where we settle directly with the insurance company so that the customer does not have to pay in advance. If you are interested, we would be happy to advise you. We wish you a good time. Best regards, Vet Trust Team Regensdorf (Original) Sehr geehrter Herr Kunde Es tut uns leid, dass sie unseren Service so wahrgenommen haben. Unsere TherapieansÃ¤tze beruhen stets auf einem medizinischen Hintergrund. Medikamente, welche unterstÃ¼tzend wirken, haben durchaus ihre Berechtigung. Sie helfen den Heilungsprozess zu beschleunigen und das Wohlbefinden der Tiere zu steigern. Ein gutes Beispiel dafÃ¼r ist ein Hautallergiker, der nur Juckreizstiller bekommt, ohne dass man unterstÃ¼tzend die Funktion der Hautbarriere verbessert. Dieses Tier wird viel hÃ¤ufiger Probleme haben, als eines welches unterstÃ¼tzende Medikamente erhÃ¤lt. Um rezeptpflichte Medikamente verschreiben zu kÃ¶nnen, mÃ¼ssen wir die Tiere zuerst klinisch untersuchen, um zu beurteilen, ob eine Medikamentengabe angebracht ist. Speziell bei Antibiotikagabe mÃ¼ssen wir das Tier vorher immer sehen, da sich im klinischen Bild etwas geÃ¤ndert haben kann und das Antibiotikum nun nicht mehr indiziert ist. Das Verschreiben von Antibiotika ist gesetzlich streng geregelt. Als TierÃ¤rzte mÃ¼ssen wir jedes Antibiotikum, das wir verschreiben der Swissmedic melden. Es ist essentiell, dass die Antibiotikagabe indiziert ist, da man mit wiederholter Gabe ohne eindeutige Indikation Resistenzen zÃ¼chten kann, was leider immer mehr der Fall ist und in Zukunft auch zu einem grossen Problem werden kann, wenn wir nicht umsichtig damit umgehen. Deshalb geht es uns keineswegs um Profit, sondern vielmehr um die Gesundheit aller Tiere, da wir auch in Zukunft mit Antibiotika arbeiten wollen. Schweizweit gilt in allen Standorten bei VetTrust Sofortzahlung. Bei grÃ¶sseren BetrÃ¤gen muss ein Teil angezahlt werden, den Rest kÃ¶nnen Kunden dann per Rechnung bezahlen. Da uns bewusst ist, dass viele Kunden bei hÃ¶heren Kosten in Schwierigkeiten kommen, haben wir zusammen mit der Versicherung SmartPaws eine spezielle Versicherung entwickelt, bei der wir direkt mit der Versicherung abrechnen, so dass der Kunde nicht in Vorleistung gehen muss. Wenn Sie Interesse daran haben, beraten wir Sie gerne. Wir wÃ¼nschen Ihnen eine gute Zeit. Herzliche GrÃ¼sse, VetTrust Team Regensdorf

Cats often need to have their teeth extracted. The dental X-ray can ensure that the entire root has been removed, which otherwise often causes problems, rsp. the gums are not healing properly. text: (Translated by Google) A while ago I brought my cat to the practice with an apparent toothache. The vet in charge examined her while I was waiting (because of Corona) in front of the treatment room. Finally she came to me with some horrible news: there was talk of a complete dental revision, which would quickly cost 1700 - 1800 francs. In addition, my cat has very dull fur and has lost about 200 grams in the last 2 years, which is why the vet tipped it to be kidney disease. My objections that the condition of the fur could also have external influences and that a weight loss of 200 grams in 2 years is not dramatic were ignored. Fear continued to be stoked even as I burst into tears of despair. Instead of being empathetic to me, I then heard from the doctor: "Well, you have to tell me now how things are going. Why are you crying? Is it about the money?". Blood was then taken from my cat to see the kidney values, which were perfectly fine. As for the very high cost estimate: I introduced my cat to my new vet today: Costs for sedation and tartar removal + possible tooth removal: approx. 300 - 350 Fr. Perhaps the doctor in charge would like to tell me how she came up with this insane amount and why she obviously values â€‹â€‹scaremongering. Ausserdem habe meine Katze sehr stumpfen Fell und in den letzten 2 Jahren ca. 200 Gramm abgenommen, weshalb die TierÃ¤rztin auf eine Nierenerkrankung tippte. Es wurde weiterhin die Angst geschÃ¼rt, auch als ich schon vor Verzweiflung in TrÃ¤nen ausbrach. Statt empathisch auf mich einzugehen, hÃ¶rte ich dann von der Ã„rztin: "Also, sie mÃ¼ssen mir jetzt schon sagen, wie es weitergeht. Warum weinen Sie denn? Geht es ums Geld?". We tried to inhale again at home in the evening with our hangover according to the prescription, as we were shown. He panicked and fought back. text: Very bad experience with this vet. We had to put our dog down and they played an important role in the suffering of our dog. I would recommend to go directly to vet hospital in Reikweil, as there they have experienced vets, specialist and have all in place to perform whatever is needed. To respond to the vetâ€™s answer. It was not my goal to start an online discussion, nor going into the details what had happened, but your answer is not correct, and I think it is important to have things clear. Lola slipped and hurt her leg the night before. The next day in the morning I phoned to ask for an appointment as soon as possible, as my dog had difficulties to come up and she was in pain. We could not come immediately to the vet, earliest at 13h as there was an operation on going, but maybe the vet could receive us earlier, we would get a phone call at 10 and in case the operation was sooner finished we could come earlier. At 11h I got the phone call, but we could not come before 14h. As Lola was laying on her pillow and was not suffering, I agreed. Lola could get up and walk (which the vet even has witnessed), of course with difficulties and for sure she had pain. She could also sit, as she was sitting the whole drive from home to the vet. I regret then I did not insist to be present when the made the X-Ray, we can only tell the results of it: After the X-Ray, the vet explained us that our dog was in shock and in a lot of pain, when I lift her later up and put her on the ground her leg was not more in a natural position and she was suffering all the time. When we ask how this happened, the vet told us that they needed to stretch the dog legs to make the X-Ray. Walking and sitting were part of the history since then. You suggesting that you already knew that my dog had an acute trauma, if that would be the case, even with having only the smallest suspicion that it could be an acute trauma, you should have send us directly to the hospital, as you do not have the equipmentâ€™s in place to treat an animal with this condition. We could have made this X-Ray then in the hospital and they can, in case something goes wrong, react as should be. About the given relieve/injection for dog for the drive. I had to ask the vet to give my dog something for the pain. First the vet told me that this would not be a good idea, as the dog could get unwell from the injection. Luckily, the vet changed his mind, and did put an injection, which should start working, according the vet, after 15 minutes. But the reality is that it never had start working. I assume that you specified the distance (25KM) to the hospital to indicate it is not so far away. We can tell you that when you have a dog in such a pain, standing on three legs, every movement of the car made her unstable and made her cry. My wife tried to stabilize the dog during the whole ride, to reduce her pain as maximum possible. We can ensure you that then 25KM is an awfully long drive. The dog cried all the way and so did we. It was a traumatic and difficult episode for all.

text: Dear All, the disappointed that I have for this Klink can't be described. As soon as the dog manifested the first synthon of urine infection, I want in this clinic, because my local veterinary was full. The veterinary gave me antibiotic, and I want there after a week for a control. She didn't do any blood test and she didn't check which bacteria it has. On the first visit she believed that the dog was 9 years old, because they have reported bad the age of the dog, WHICH WAS JUST ONE YEAR OLD. She told me that the infection was better after a week, but even after telling her that it's clinical condition were the same. She just suggested to wait another week. She told me that urine infection can take 2 weeks to be fully cured. I didn't trust her anymore, so after 3 days from the second visit I want to my local veterinary, that just with a blood test she told me to go immediately to the Tierspital. The infection it has was not curable with the antibiotic the veterinary of this clinic gave me. So after 10 days the infection reached the kidney and it was not responding to infusion therapy. So in order to try to save him they did dialysis. The dog unfortunately didn't survive. These costed me in total around 14'000 CHF, I would like to file a complaint. But I don't want to invest any more money in this story. Next time my dog its not getting any better after some days, I will go immediately to Tierspital. AND OF COURSE I WILL NEVER COME BACK IN THIS CLINIC. Even after talking with the veterinary of this clinic she didn't even apologize and what make me hungry is that in her believe she didn't do any mistake in her diagnosis .

text: (Translated by Google) Unfortunately, the "trust" is not the program here. Unfortunately, I had to take two different pets there in a short time as an emergency because my vet was on vacation. The first time, a vet took care of us, who m.W. used to be at TÃ¼Z Tenniken (they were known for their VERY good work). He was characterized by excellent handling of the animal and also the human companionship (me). He took his time, explained everything clearly and thoroughly, examined everything thoroughly. After this positive experience, I later came to the clinic with another pet as an emergency. Even the handling at the beginning was extremely disorganized this time. Despite prior appointment, we sat in the waiting room for 50 minutes! When we were finally asked into the room, we were left to wait alone for another 15 minutes. Then a young doctor walked in who didn't even introduce himself. I explained the reason for our visit and without even having taken the animal out of the transport box, the doctor dared to make a diagnosis using X-ray vision based on my rough description of the symptoms. In his view, euthanasia is the only option. Keep in mind: WITHOUT having looked at and examined the animal at all and you really couldn't speak of clear symptoms (there was no bad general condition or anything - and in any case I expect that no matter what the owner describes, the animal is looked at and examined. How else would a doctor know how the animal is doing and whether the owner has correctly identified all the symptoms?). My animal therefore had to suffer unnecessarily for a few days without painkillers before our standard vet returned from vacation a few days later and gave us an emergency appointment. By the way, euthanasia was not necessary. I was deeply shocked by this experience. Since you can't TRUST that you will be treated competently and decently at this clinic, I will definitely not go here again. VetUntrust. (Original) Das "Trust" ist hier leider nicht Programm. Musste leider in kurzer Zeit notfallmÃ¤ssig mit zwei verschiedenen Haustieren dort hin, weil mein Tierarzt im Urlaub war. Beim ersten Mal versorgte uns ein Tierarzt, der m.W. frÃ¼her beim TÃ¼Z Tenniken war (die waren bekannt fÃ¼r ihre SEHR gute Arbeit). Er zeichnete sich durch hervorragenden Umgang mit dem Tier und auch der menschlichen Begleitung (mir) aus. Er nahm sich Zeit, erklÃ¤rte alles gut und verstÃ¤ndlich, untersuchte grÃ¼ndlich. Nach dieser positiven Erfahrung kam ich notfallmÃ¤ssig spÃ¤ter mit einem weiteren Haustier in die Klinik. Schon die Abwicklung am Anfang war diesmal extrem unorganisiert. Trotz vorheriger Terminabsprache sassen wir 50Min im Wartezimmer! Als wir endlich ins Zimmer gebeten wurden, liess man uns dort nochmal 15Min alleine warten. Dann kam ein junger Arzt herein, der sich nichtmal vorstellte. Ich schilderte den Grund unseres Besuchs und ohne das Tier Ã¼berhaupt aus der Transportbox geholt zu haben, traute sich der Arzt per RÃ¶ntgenblick anhand meiner groben Symptomschilderung zu, eine Diagnose zu stellen. Seiner Ansicht nach sei EinschlÃ¤fern die einzige Option. Man halte fest: OHNE das Tier Ã¼berhaupt angeschaut und untersucht zu haben und von eindeutigen Symptomen konnte man nun wirklich nicht sprechen (es lag auch kein schlechter Allgemeinzustand vor oder so - und in jedem Fall erwarte ich, dass egal was der Besitzer schildert, das Tier angeschaut und untersucht wird. Woher will man als Arzt sonst wissen, wie es dem Tier geht und ob der Besitzer alle Symptome richtig erkannt hat?). Mein Tier musste deshalb unnÃ¶tig einige Tage ohne Schmerzmittel leiden bevor einige Tage spÃ¤ter unser Standard-Tierarzt aus dem Urlaub zurÃ¼ck war und uns NotfallmÃ¤ssig einen Termin gab. EinschlÃ¤fern war dann Ã¼brigens nicht nÃ¶tig. Ich war von diesem Erlebnis zutiefst schockiert. Da man bei dieser Klinik nicht darauf VERTRAUEN kann, kompetent und anstÃ¤ndig behandelt zu werden, werde ich ganz sicher nicht mehr hier hin gehen. VetUntrust.
(Translated by Google) Friendly staff. good doctors (Original) Freundliches Personal. Gute Ã„rzte

(Translated by Google) My first impression of the emergency appointment was very negative. The resident doctor in charge (did not introduce himself) treated my suffering cat with a very bad abscess / phlegmon rather unlovingly and like an object, he was also very loud and showed me neither empathy nor understanding for the very difficult situation at the moment. I found this treatment so serious because my cat had previously been misdiagnosed and treated incorrectly by the veterinarian, which led to an emergency operation at the VetTrust Clinic. So the trust in TA was just pretty shaken. On the part of the first resident, a personal and loving attention to the animal and a more respectful behavior towards me would have been quite appropriate. In general, there should be no gap between a veterinarian and an emotionally troubled pet owner seeking help, with the former demonstrating their current power over circumstances. The findings communicated orally at the emergency appointment were made by the same person in technical jargon and diagnostically. In my view, a diagnostically oriented person with a lack of social skills is out of place for an emergency treatment of an animal and does little to calm the animal and its owner. The assistant vet who then operated was correct and took the time to answer my questions during the follow-up treatment. But I also had to ask him several times because I didn't understand his specialist descriptions and I also missed the loving way he treated my animal. During the 12-day treatment I also had a veterinarian, Mrs. HÃ¤mmerle, who treated my anxious cat very lovingly and also called him by his name, which I expect from a vet per se. What was irritating was the different opinions of the veterinarians working there. A vet recommended a bodysuit for my cat after it understandably showed depressive behavior after seven days of wearing a ruff, others were against it and would not have given one. My cat then got rid of the body itself overnight, which I wasn't prepared for / potentially wasn't prepared for and he was therefore able to lick the wound. That was an additional stress for me! I think that in a practice, relevant attitudes should be presented to the outside world in a uniform manner, otherwise the pet owner will become very insecure and the credibility of the practice will begin to falter. (Translated by Google) Dear Ms. Loepfe, First of all, I would like to thank you very much for taking the time for us so quickly at the Kleintierklinik am Damm. Our Milo behaved very atypically for him over the weekend. He's usually a bright, energetic dog who enjoys exploring the outdoors and letting us know if anything seems odd to him. Then over the weekend he started acting strange, sleeping a lot, walking stiffly and like he was in pain. However, he still ate quite well, but with everything he did he seemed quickly tired and sometimes apathetic. I got an appointment on Monday morning, where Ms. Loepfe took her time and asked good questions. Since there was pain in the room at this point, he was given painkillers and stomach protectors to see whether this therapy would improve. Unfortunately, his condition deteriorated extremely in the evening. He got a high fever, which we tried to bring down during the night. I was able to get an emergency appointment the very next morning. We decided together that Milo would stay in the practice for the time being and some tests would be done. The option of him having to go to a special clinic was discussed with me. A few hours later I got the call from Mrs. Loepfe that she would like to transfer Milo to a special clinic because she suspected motion sickness. From my point of view, Ms. Loepfe has done a very good job here. She always informed me and answered my questions and took the time to do so. The first direction taken (pain reduction) had become obsolete (of course, the medication is now lying around at home unused), but the picture that Milo had shown up to that point was also unspecific from my point of view and therefore the therapy was justified in my opinion. I would like to emphasize, above all because the costs and the diagnoses made have been criticized several times: In my opinion, a veterinarian can only be as good as the information he gets a) from the owner and b) from the animal itself receives. Some animals are not masters at showing that they are in a bad way, or only very late. So if certain symptoms are hidden and/or they are not noticed by the owner and therefore cannot be reported, the best vet can only make a limited diagnosis. Otherwise, the other side of the coin would be to do a lot of testing. These cost money, which is just as often a point of criticism. After the referral, Milo began some examinations in a clinic of our choice. Finally yesterday evening the diagnosis of stage III leishmaniasis was made here. Even in the veterinary clinic on the dam, some values â€‹â€‹were seen that could indicate such a diagnosis. Therefore, I would like to thank Mrs. Loepfe and the chief physician again for their good preparatory work, which must have made it easier for the colleagues in the current treating clinic to be able to make this diagnosis so quickly. text: (Translated by Google) My cat Blacky "Cicer" has been given a second life. Cicer had been a house cat for two and a half years. In my new apartment I let him - a bit restless inside - go on a journey of discovery outside for the first time. It had gone well a few times. Early in the morning of May 16, I realizedâ€”Cicer was shaking his head oddlyâ€”that something was wrong. At 4 a.m. I was already at the veterinary clinic on Damm in Gossau. The doctor present showed me the large open flesh wound on the left rear leg. The stomach was also open. She operated on my cat for the first time as an emergency. That was the beginning of a great adventure. Up until the beginning of September, my cat had been operated on several times, and the bandage had to be changed again and again. The skin had to be re-stitched each time. My inner questions were, "Will he survive? Isn't he in too much pain?" His life was on the brink of blood poisoning. Inside I was very excited, in great concern. At first he didn't eat and lay almost motionless at my house for hours. I was shaken. After the second operation he started to eat again - what a feeling of happiness inside me. That was the visible sign for me that he wanted to live as a fighter. I knew that together with the doctors, Mrs. Tanja KÃ¼nzle, Mrs. Roxane Feurer, the head of the Klinik am Damm, Mr. AndrÃ© KÃ¼nzle, and the various veterinary assistants, I would do everything to save his life and leg. It is now towards the end of October, Cicer has been back at my house for some time. He is doing well, he is as healthy as before the big accident: strong, agile, self-confident, curious, he lives as before. And I'm just grateful. I would like to thank the whole team at the veterinary clinic from the bottom of my heart, especially Mrs. Tanja KÃ¼nzle. Cicer has been given a new life. And I feel almost the same way. Brought my dog in for not eating, diahrea, dehydration and puking. After ultrasonic they recommended intestinal surgery with a reportedly high chance of success. Since he was fit for his age, I consented. Three days postoperatively he got worse and a second ultrasonic revealed fluid buildup in the abdominal cavity. A suture was leaking digestive fluids. I consented to them opening him up again, wash it all down with antiseptic and fix the leakage, again they where confident this was a course of action with a good chance of success. My dog died under anesthesia, probably too much for his heart (which was strong) in combination with septic shock. I paid 4600.- for this. 1. Surgeons giving optimistic asessments, should not have believed them. 2. Probably didnt check for leakage with saline solution/gas or dyes. 3. Didnt run septic biomarkers until day 3 after surgery, could have probaly cought the issue early, with much better outlook.

text: (Translated by Google) My cat was in the clinic from Saturday evening to Monday afternoon (fever and hadn't eaten or drunk anything). At first it was said that everything was fine so far, just dehydrated and that she was given an IV on the night. The next morning it was said that she had free air in her abdomen, which could be a perforated intestinal obstruction. An ultrasound would have to be done to rule that out. The examination should be done as soon as possible, because in the worst case an operation would have to be carried out. I haven't received any information for a long time, so I kept calling them myself. The investigation was repeatedly postponed until later. Since the ultrasound cannot rule out the occlusion with certainty, an ultrasound is performed again the next day (in the morning). I called again and was told that the examination had been postponed to later in the morning and then again to the afternoon because a specialist would not be in the clinic until then (an X-ray with contrast medium was not wanted because of possible complications.) . When I found out that it was going to be later again, I informed my vet who (like me) couldn't understand that so much time was wasted on this suspected diagnosis. The longer the intestinal obstruction lasts, the more tissue is destroyed and the prognosis steadily worsens. Not wanting to wait any longer, I informed the clinic that I would pick her up and take her to the vet, who would do the x-rays and be able to react faster (like the clinic is currently doing). After this call, there was suddenly an expert in the house who could do the ultrasound... That's very questionable and not professional for me! Conclusion: An X-ray and ultrasound were made from Sa-Mo. She received an infusion and shortly before I picked her up cortisone, nothing more. Despite a careful search, my veterinarian could not see any air in the abdominal cavity. The communication in the team is not really apparent to me, since no one could really tell me whether she ate or not. I was not informed about the costs, but I could have asked myself. I will pay the generous bill (4 digits) but I will not come back to the Vettrust Clinic. You have received a letter with the timeline and further details by email. Something positive: Mr. Dr Hasler seemed very competent and Ms. Nussbaum was very friendly/helpful. (Original) Meine Katze war (Fieber und nichts gefressen/ getrunken) von Sa Abend bis Mo Nachmittag stationÃ¤r in der Klinik. Zuerst hiess es, es sei soweit alles gut, nur dehydriert und sie bekomme Ã¼ber Nacht Infusion. Am nÃ¤chsten Morgen hiess es dann, sie habe freie Luft im Bauchraum was ein perforierter Darmverschluss sein kÃ¶nne. Es mÃ¼sse ein Ultraschall gemacht werden um dies auszuschliessen. Die Untersuchung solle so schnell wie mÃ¶glich gemacht werden, da sie schlimmstenfalls operiert werden mÃ¼sse. Ich erhielt lÃ¤nger keine Informationen mehr, ich rief deshalb immer wieder selbst an. Die Untersuchung wurde immer wieder auf spÃ¤ter verschoben. Da der Ultraschall den Verschluss nicht sicher ausschliessen kÃ¶nne, werde am nÃ¤chsten Tag (am Morgen) wieder ein Ultraschall gemacht. Ich rief wieder an und erfuhr, dass die Untersuchung zeitlich auf spÃ¤ter am Vormittag verschoben wurde und dann noch einmal auf den Nachmittag verschoben wurde, da erst dann ein Spezialist in der Klinik sei (Ein RÃ¶ntgenbild mit Kontrastmittel wolle man wegen mÃ¶glichen Komplikationen nicht machen.). Als ich erfuhr, dass es wieder spÃ¤ter werden sollte, informierte ich meinen Haustierarzt, welcher (wie ich) nicht verstehen konnte, dass bei dieser Verdachtsdiagnose so viel Zeit verloren wurde. Umso lÃ¤nger der Darmverschluss besteht, umso mehr Gewebe geht kaputt und die Prognose verschlechtert sich stetig. Als ich nicht noch lÃ¤nger warten wollte, informierte ich die Klinik, dass ich sie abhole und zum Haustierarzt bringe, der die RÃ¶ntgenuntersuchung mache und so schneller reagieren kÃ¶nne (wie momentan in der Klinik). Nach diesem Anruf war dann plÃ¶tzlich doch ein Experte im Haus, der den Ultraschall machen konnteâ€¦Das ist fÃ¼r micht sehr fragwÃ¼rdig und nicht Professionell! Fazit: Von Sa-Mo wurde ein RÃ¶ntgen und Ultraschall gemacht. Sie erhielt Infusion und kurz bevor ich sie abholte noch Kortison, mehr nicht. Mein Haustierarzt konnte trotz genauem Suchen, keinerlei Luft im Bauchraum sehen. Die Kommunikation im Team ist fÃ¼r mich nicht wirklich ersichtlich, da mir auch niemand wirklich sagen konnte, ob sie gefressen habe oder nicht. Ãœber die Kosten wurde ich nicht informiert, hÃ¤tte aber auch selbst nachfragen kÃ¶nnen. Ich werde die GrosszÃ¼gige Rechnung (4 Stellig) bezahlen aber ich werde nicht wieder in die Vettrust Klinik kommen. Sie haben ein Schreiben mit dem zeitlichen Ablauf und weiteren Details per Mail erhalten. Etwas positives: Hr. Dr Hasler wirkte sehr kompetent und Frau Nussbaum war sehr freundlich/ Hilfsbereit .

text: (Translated by Google) We went to this vet clinic last Saturday for an emergency. Our dog had started limping on the front leg the previous Friday. Instead of checking the affected area, he looked at the hind legs and didn't touch them for 2 minutes and said you have to operate because the knees are loose and the ligaments are torn and that the costs of 1300 to 1600 are incurred. What shoud that? First, scare the pet owners + just think about the money? No interest in health! Nothing was x-rayed and not even examined in peace. The main thing is to quickly write a report for our vet and send it off to us. We got painkillers and had to pay 340.00 for the visit! Instead of paying 100 on the phone, you billed us for 160! + 160.- for 2 min consultation. Even the receptionists said goodbye, I hope you think well about the surgery, it's not cheap either. The week after we went to our trusted vet and he couldn't find anything! The diagnosis was incorrect! We were with him for 30 minutes and he checked everything. Our dog can walk again without any problems and has no complaints. (Original) Wir waren letzten Samstag bei dieser Tierklinik fÃ¼r ein Notfall.
